response_text:

But “tallest” can mean other things, so the safest approach is to be explicit about which measure you mean.

Which authoritative sources to consult
- Nepal’s Department of Survey — they led the 2020 re-survey of Everest and published the official Nepalese number.  
- China’s national surveying agency (the joint Nepal–China announcement, Dec 2020).  
- Peer‑reviewed geodesy literature and technical reports on the 2020 survey (GPS/GNSS methodology, ellipsoid/geoid used). Look in journals like Journal of Geodesy or technical reports from national mapping agencies.  
- International reference data from:
  - NASA (Earth Observatory, SRTM data and missions)  
  - USGS (mountain elevation background and mapping)  
  - IERS / WGS84 documentation (for definitions of distance to Earth’s center and datums)  
- Encyclopaedia Britannica or National Geographic for clear lay explanations and comparisons.  
- Guinness World Records (for “highest mountain” records, but check their definition and source).  
- Mountain/geography specialist sites for alternate measures (Peakbagger, Peaklist) when checking prominence or base-to-summit claims.

What to check in those sources (a quick verification checklist)
- Which definition of “tallest/highest” is being used (above mean sea level; from base; farthest from Earth’s center; topographic prominence).  
- The datum/geoid/ellipsoid used (e.g., mean sea level vs WGS84). That affects wording about “above sea level” vs “distance from Earth’s center.”  
- Date and method of measurement (e.g., the 2020 Nepal–China GNSS survey, older surveys, satellite/altimetry). Earthquakes can change heights slightly.  
- Any uncertainty or margin of error stated.

Key factual distinctions you may want to use on-air
- Highest summit above sea level: Mount Everest. (Latest joint Nepal–China announcement put Everest at 8,848.86 m.)  
- Tallest measured from base to summit: Mauna Kea (Hawaii) — about 4,207 m above sea level but ~10,200 m from its base on the ocean floor to the summit.  
- Farthest from the Earth’s center: Chimborazo (Ecuador) — because Earth is an oblate spheroid, Chimborazo’s summit is the point on Earth’s surface farthest from the center, even though its elevation above sea level (~6,263 m) is less than Everest’s.  
- Most topographically prominent: Everest is also the most prominent (prominence = height of summit’s rise above the lowest contour encircling it and no higher summit).

Exact on-air wording you can use (short and safe)
- If you want a short correction that preserves the guest’s intent:
  - “That’s true if you mean ‘highest above sea level’: Mount Everest’s summit is the highest point on Earth above mean sea level.”

A slightly longer script for a fact-check segment
- “Fact-check: When people say ‘Everest is the tallest mountain,’ they usually mean ‘highest above sea level,’ which is correct — Everest’s summit is the highest point on Earth above mean sea level (8,848.86 m, per the 2020 Nepal–China survey). But ‘tallest’ can mean other things: by height from base to summit, Mauna Kea is larger (about 10.2 km from its submarine base), and because the Earth bulges at the equator, Chimborazo’s summit is actually the farthest point from Earth’s center. So Everest is the highest above sea level, but not the sole possible meaning of ‘tallest.’”

If you need to cite quickly on air or in text
- Cite the Nepal Department of Survey / the joint Nepal–China announcement (Dec 2020) for Everest’s current official height. For comparisons, cite NASA/USGS and National Geographic articles explaining Mauna Kea and Chimborazo distinctions, or reputable geodesy sources.

If you want, I can:
